comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Thanks, and no, we'd moved on to Rome by time of second quake!

They are beautiful nibs, and you're right, the 11-1/2 is gorgeus, isn't it? Don't think we've come across that in any of our photos yet. I did try some of the headlines that I could make out in our online newspapers for dating purposes but couldn't find any exact matches...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I wonder if the Premier's trenchant speech referenced in the Weekly Freeman is Asquith in Dublin in July 1912?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Bonar Law, Home Rule, Balkan War (1912 & 1913 according to Wikipedia). I'd say 1912.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Does the Freeman billboard say "Parliament Opens"?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Yes, I think so!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Just wondering about the "Parliament Opens". State opening was usually November/December unless in an election year. Was 1912 an election year??
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
"The First Balkan War broke out when the League attacked Turkey on 8 October 1912"  - Wikipedia
Parliament opened on  7th October 1912 after the summer recess. (they had adjourned at 9:30 on August 7th)
The 'closure debate' on 10th October was devoted to the Home Rule Bill - the speakers included Asquith and Bonar Law

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I'm going put my money on Saturday July 20th 1912. That's the date the Freemans' Journal reported on Asquith's speech: "The Prime Minister's speech last night in Dublin was not only a speech, but a political event of first rate importance and fraught with consequence".

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: ... aaand John makes me look wrong before I even hit "post"!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Oh well, at least it was only virtual money! Well done, [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] ! Now then - anyone know the day of the week that the Weekly Freeman and the Weekly Irish Times were published? If we can tie them in to some of the papers (magazines?) like Tit-Bits, we may be able to get an exact date in October (give or take a day)...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: On Saturday 12th of October, the Irish Times had a story called "Powers and the Balkan Coalition", which may explain what that illegible headline is: POWERS & BALKANS

comment.author: 16823801@N00
comment._content:
Seeing the Bolands Bread wagon reminds me of when I was a child during the 2nd WW in Brownstown  on the Curragh  Kildare  One of our neighbours  drove a similar Bolands  van that lived in a corrugated iron "garage" which  if  I remember also served as an occasional illegal slaughter house to provide bacon in hard times!  To a childish eye the van seemed a great deal bigger and was horse drawn which must have presented problems as we were around 30 miles from Dublin
 I wonder if anyone else has any memory of this and can complete the story??. .

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: They come as a boon and a blessing to men, The Pickwick, the Owl and the Waverley Pen. and 3007 Newspapers recommend them.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Field's (the stationers) was run by 2 sisters. According to 1911 census, the shop was run by Emily Field and her sister Florence Field. Both in their 40s and originally from England. They were assisted by their niece Adelaide. Two elderly aunts also lived at 11a. They were all single and self reliant ladies!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Fantastic! And what a random number - 3007. Makes you inclined to believe them, rather than if they'd said 3000 newspapers recommend them...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Absolutely brilliant information on the Misses Field. Thank you! Reminds me of the two sisters who used to run Parson's Bookshop on Baggot Street Bridge...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
